title: many systems split into client-server pairs
“Client” and “Server” are merely roles relative to one interface
Client-server relationship can be cascaded (just like nesting)
an interface consists of a set of related operations

Remote Procedure Calls intend to provide us the illusion that a program is running locally rather than on another system. RPCs are an abstraction that can reduce the complexity in programming a distributed system.
The system guarantees the local semantics assuming that a server machine that crashes will eventually restart. It keeps track of
orphan calls
b

, that is, calls on server machines that have crashed, and allows them to be later adopted by a new server. These semantics and their implementation were proposed in Bruce Nelson's thesis, but because of the complexity of the implementation, were never implemented as far as I know.
success return from RPC call → call executed exactly once
call blocks indefinitely, no failure return
guarantee true even across server and network failures

The call executes at most once - either it does not execute at all or it executes exactly once depending on whether the server machine goes down. Once delivered, there is no chance of delivering again. If the consumer is unable to handle the message due to some exception, the message is
lost
b
. These semantics require the
detection of duplicate
b
packets, but work for
non-idempotent operations
b
success return from RPC call → call executed at most once
if timeout is ambiguous: call may or may not have been successful
still guaranteed to be never more than once
Most RPC packages provide at-most-once RPC
The call executes at least once as long as the server machine does not fail. These semantics require very
little overhead
and are
easy to implement
. The client machine continues to send call requests to the server machine until it gets an acknowledgement. There is high chance that message will be delivered again as
duplicate
b
. If one or more acknowledgements are lost, the server may execute the call multiple times. This approach works only if the requested operation is
idempotent
b
, that is, multiple invocations of it return the same result. Servers that implement only idempotent operations must be
stateless
b
, that is, must not change global state in response to client requests. Thus, RPC systems that support these semantics rely on the design of stateless servers.
example: read() request on locked object or read-only object
example: current_stock_price(MSFT). semantics of operation allows any valid price after issue of request to be returned

completely stateless

Failure
b
is independent between clients and servers
Client and server do not share address space
pointers don’t mean the same thing at the two ends, embedded pointers in parameters useless
As a result, parameters need to be
serialized/marshalled/packed
b
so they can be sent between client and server. Data stored on the heap using pointers needs to be converted into a pointer-less format that doesn’t depend on address space of one machine.
Failure independence of clients and servers
in local case, client and server live or die together
in remote case, client see new failure modes
failure handling code has to be more thorough (and more complex)

remote RPC implementation may not be trusted!
